awd_titl_txt: CSEDI Collaborative Research:  Towards a unified model of the geomagnetic, geochemical, and thermal evolutions of Earth's mantle and core
awd_abstract_narration:
The magnetic field of the Earth, generated inside the fluid portion of Earth's Iron core, protects the Earth and orbiting satellites from a barrage of potentially harmful charged particles streaming through space.   The magnetization of ancient rocks has shown us that the magnetic field has been shielding Earth for at least 3.5 billion years.  Beyond that age, there are no observations currently available to assess if a magnetic field was present.  It is a mystery when exactly the magnetic field arose, and also a challenging puzzle as to how it has been sustained for billions of years.  The answers to those questions will greatly impact our understanding of how our Earth evolved from its initial state into a habitable planet able to develop and sustain life on its surface.  The proposed research aims to take a new approach to answer these difficult questions by looking at the role a deep magma ocean overlying Earth's core might have played in helping sustain an ancient magnetic field.

	Recent experiments that are able to simulate the extreme pressures and temperatures within Earth's deep interior have provided new knowledge on how Earth materials behave under such conditions.  Using this recently gained information on material properties, in conjunction with theoretical considerations of the energetics of magnetic field generation, this project will build physics-based models of Earth's interior and cooling through time.  These efforts will specifically investigate scenarios in which there is a long-lived magma ocean on top of the core.  These models will test if this scenario can explain the generation of Earth's magnetic field during ancient times.  While we will learn directly about the Earth's deep interior, this work impacts our understanding of surface processes as well, since the magnetic shielding of highly charged particles aimed at Earth (or lack thereof) will affect the atmosphere and surface of the Earth.

por.por_cntn:
This project's goal was to assess the hypothesis that the Earth’s ancient magnetic field was generated within a molten region at the base of the Earth's mantle. An outcome of this project was to develop software capable of calculating both the energy balance and entropy balance of a solidifying basal magma ocean in the Earth's mantle to describe the thermal evolution and geomagnetic histories that are possible in such a situation. The software delivered as an outcome of this project is computational infrastructure that is generalized and applicable to many other scenarios besides a basal magma ocean in Earth's mantle. The software has been made publicly available. The project supported a team to develop this software, primarily a female post-doctoral scholar that lead the development effort, and members of the team continue to develop this after the completion of the project. During the project, there were 2 peer-reviewed journal articles published in top tier journals, and additional publications in the next few years are expected to follow. A major outcome of this project was salary support for postdoctoral scholar from an underrepresented group (single mother with 2 school age children) to gain skills and experience in a discipline that was different from the discipline of her PhD.  The employment of a young scientist in this context offered invaluable professional development for the postdoctoral scholar as it opened up new professional networks, further established her ability in pursueing scholarship that was independent from her PhD advisor and previous collaborations, and demonstrated an ability to work on interdisciplinary topics that are at the forefront of the scientific priorities of the deep earth geophysics community. Another outcome of this project was strengthening of an existing international collaboration between PI-Stegman and C. Davies (Univ. Leeds, UK) who continue to work together on various scientific topics. An indirect outcome of this project was to provide further motivation to researchers with specializations in core dynamics and paleomagnetism to consider more broadly what evidence and mechanisms exist for the ancient magnetic field of the Earth, including the possibility of Earth having had a continuously operating magnetic field beginning just after the formation of the Earth's core, instead of the starting only when the earliest evidence for its existence.
